p: While there are multiple high-priority health needs, some services are traditionally more broadly recognised as such than others. Historically, contraception and SAC have been described as ‘elective’ or ‘on request,’ and therefore not universally considered essential, or in some cases even legitimate, healthcare. 8 Despite its impact on reducing maternal and infant mortality, contraception is often regarded more in terms of its socioeconomic benefit on development than as a life-saving health service. 9 Similarly, in much of the world, political controversies around abortion overshadow the reality that SAC is healthcare. Even though abortion is very common—an estimated one in four pregnancies end in abortion—it is also highly stigmatised. 10
